title: Tinnitus and Hyperacusis following Acoustic Shock
chief_complaint: I have ringing in my ears and I am afraid to return to work because of the pain caused by the noise levels there. It started two weeks ago when a caller unexpectedly yelled in my ear while I was wearing my headset.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset 2 weeks prior to evaluation.
problem_summary.course: Started immediately after an acoustic incident (caller yelling in headset); symptoms are persistent and severe.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Pain, anxiety, fear of loud sounds, spasms, aural fullness, reduced sleep and concentration.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severe reaction to moderately loud sounds; locks herself in her room; unable to work.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to reduce pain and fear to return to work.

history.present_illness: Patient works in a call center (70 calls/day). 2 weeks ago, a caller yelled while she was wearing a headset. She experienced immediate bilateral tinnitus, pain, anxiety, and fear. She now has severe reactions to moderately loud sounds (hyperacusis).
history.otologic_history: Reports frequent pain, spasms, and aural fullness in both ears. 'Ear popping' and distorted speech.
history.noise_exposure_history: Call center environment with ~50 other employees talking simultaneously.
history.medical_psych_history: Seen by PCP and pain specialist; TMJ disorder ruled out.
history.patient_goals: Relief from pain and sound sensitivity.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild bilateral symmetrical Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL), essentially flat in configuration.

numeric_results.Configuration: Flat thresholds approx 25-35 dB HL across 250-8000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Word Recognition Scores (WRS) obtained at Most Comfortable Level (65 dB HL) due to loudness discomfort at standard levels. Normal recognition in right ear, slight difficulty in left.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, static admittance, and middle ear pressure (Type A).

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs)
tests.key_findings: LDLs hovered around 70 to 80 dB HL, which is lower than expected for mild hearing loss, indicating hyperacusis/reduced sound tolerance.

tests.name: Tinnitus Assessment
tests.key_findings: High-pitched continuously ringing sound. Minimum Masking Levels (MML) could not be identified as masking noise was too uncomfortable.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mild, flat, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. However, the primary findings are significant reduced sound tolerance (hyperacusis) with LDLs ranging from 70-80 dB HL and bothersome tinnitus matched to 4000 Hz. Speech recognition is good but testing required reduced presentation levels due to discomfort.
counseling_points: Your symptoms are consistent with Tonic Tensor Tympani Syndrome (TTTS) following acoustic shock.
Although loud sounds are annoying or painful, they are unlikely to damage your hearing further.
Overprotecting your ears (using earplugs constantly) can actually make the hyperacusis worse by increasing the brain's sensitivity.
We will use sound therapy (Widex Zen) and gradual desensitization to help your brain filter out the tinnitus and tolerate normal sounds again.
notes_for_actor: Portray significant anxiety and fear when loud sounds occur (e.g., a door closing, a chair scraping).
Describe a physical sensation of 'spasms' or 'fluttering' in your ear along with the pain.
Express reluctance to undergo testing that involves loud beeps.
